pullRequest.body:
Prove `power_sum`, a generalization of `power_add` for `Cardinal.sum`.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

For the proof I proved `induction_on_pi`, the cardinal version of `Quotient.induction_on_pi`.

For consistency in the cardinals library it should really be called `inductionOnₚᵢ`, but I'm willing to let that go.

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [42e945fd3d](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/16795/commits/42e945fd3d0442df2062d786b0b84efdfaffa1f5)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ induction_on_pi`
`+ mk_sigma_arrow`
`+ power_sum`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>
`mk_pi_congr_subtype` probably has a better name.
I like the `congr` results, I generally find this kind of stuff valuable. My request would be to have matching lemmas on `sum`.
True, making the `mk_sigma_congr` lemmas should be pretty easy and analogous to the `mk_pi` ones, but that can be an independent little PR

> True, making the `mk_sigma_congr` lemmas should be pretty easy and analogous to the `mk_pi` ones, but that can be an independent little PR

This is #16824. Let me know what you think, there's a little weirdness with the subtype version because of notation differences between `Π` and `Σ`.

:v: vihdzp can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

I found `Equiv.piCongr` and `Equiv.sigmaCongr` which gives easier proofs. I also want to add versions where the indexing types are not the same but have an equivalence, like in these theorems. These more general versions can be in another commit (I'd like to have them both since the more general one is clumsy in cases where it's not needed) but I want to make sure the naming here won't clash with them.

If we add these more general versions, what should they be named? `mk_pi_congr'` is the only one I can think of, but it's obviously not great.
I'm a ltitle suspicious of these congruence theorems for `Cardinal.mk`; usually I'd hope you can use a congruence construction for `Equiv` instead.

Given that the congruence lemmas will be moved, and that everyone likes this new proof:

bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10883037582/job/30195298286)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10883037582/job/30195297966)
The main result here looks valuable - thanks for working on it - but I'm not sure about some of the others. @vihdzp, what do you think?
bors d=@vihdzp

I'm inclined to say this shouldn't be a lemma since it does indeed follow easily from `mk_pi`. But maybe there's a bounded quantification one which doesn't follow quite so easily - `#(Π i ∈ s, f i) = #(Π i ∈ s, g i)` (with `h` adjusted to also only be in `s`)? I'm not sure, what do you think?

I like having these kinds of lemmas because in an actual use case `simp_all only [mk_pi]` won't reduce the goal this way, since it won't be this clean. Why not have this so you can easily tell lean exactly what it should do?
I'm usually leaning towards adding lemmas like this just to prevent cumulative clutter.

The generalization looks like a good idea, I'll add it.
That's fair. Let's give it the name `mk_pi_congr` then.

```suggestion
    a ^ sum f = prod fun i ↦ a ^ f i :=
```

```suggestion
    (f : ι → Cardinal.{v}) (h : ∀ f : ι → Type v, p fun i ↦ #(f i)) : p f :=
```

Does this work?
```suggestion
    rw [prod, sum]
    simp_rw [power_def]
```
Can this `simp only` and the one below be replaced by `rw`?

I couldn't, the thing to prove is basically `Equiv.symm_apply_apply` inside a bunch of binders and lambdas, and after intoducing them all you need to at least `simp_rw` anyways because it's not in exactly the right form.

What do you think of this proof, which doesn't need any of the new `congr` lemmas?
```suggestion
theorem power_sum {ι} (a : Cardinal) (f : ι → Cardinal) :
    a ^ sum f = prod fun i ↦ a ^ f i := by
  induction a using Cardinal.inductionOn with | _ α => ?_
  induction f using induction_on_pi with | _ f =>
  simp_rw [prod, sum, power_def]
  apply mk_congr
  refine (Equiv.piCurry fun _ _ => α).trans ?_
  refine Equiv.piCongrRight fun b => ?_
  refine (Equiv.arrowCongr outMkEquiv (Equiv.refl α)).trans ?_
  exact (outMkEquiv).symm
```

I'd like to hear @b-mehta's thoughts on this before merging
I still like the congruency lemmas since I always want to have more ways to reason about cardinals without reasoning about `Equiv`'s, but I'll remove them if you disagree. @vihdzp what do you think?

I'm compelled to agree. You don't usually see explicit equivalences when doing cardinal arithmetic after a certain point, instead you just use results like Cantor-Schröder to do all the heavy lifting. So being able to abstract that away is a good thing in my book.

I think so too - the fact that cardinals are defined as equivalence classes of equivs should be thought of as an implementation detail, and so the congr lemmas which allow this should stay. But the new proof is also pretty nice - surely we can have both the congr lemmas and this new proof.
I already commited the new proof, it's neat. I think I'll move all the congruency lemmas to #16824 to have all the versions in one place, now that they're not needed here.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(SetTheory/Cardinal/Basic): Prove power_sum, power of an infinite sum
